title: How to receive text messages without inserting my SIM card - Quora

response.answer_text: Use the same text phone number on the internet and receive your messages on the internet instead of a phone. I do almost all my texting on the internet, because I prefer a keyboard to my thumbs. Get yourself a google voice account and your text number can be incorporated. My GV online account links to my smartphone and a third number, even though the three numbers are not the same. If I send an email from my google voice, it will not appear on my smartphone. But if someone writes back to my GV online phone number, that voicemail will appear on my smart phone also. I’ve been asked by my bank for a textable phone number. They won’t accept my google voice number even if it would work, because its not on a list of numbers they look up that are supposedly all the possible textable numbers. But it would work anyway if they only tried it. The reason: the banks want the number I give them to be a cellphone number: that is their understanding of what a textable number is. Friends of mine routinely, incidentally, send me email via their phone numbers on their cellphones too by simply texting me. I get emails from them that have nothing but their email number as an address. I write back using my normal email address and they get what I wrote as a text. I assume you know your phone won’t communicate without a sim card in it?! But I can be reached anyway even if my cellphone isn’t on. Also, most phones when dialed will not produce a caller ID number on a called phone unless it rings twice. I get a caller ID with just one ring on google voice. My credit card company writes a short statement to my phone’s email account every time I use any credit card I have. That short statement winds up in my gmail every time that happens and appears as a text and also as an email. I have records of every call I’ve received, including texts, all the way back to August, 2009. Google Voice, incidentally, will convert a voicemail into text on my google voice program online.

Depends on what you mean as text messages if you mean actual SMS or MMS you need a service provider to receive and send those type of messages. If you're using iPhone or any free text and calling app they are strictly using WiFi signals to encode and decide messages which is not bound to any service provider, and is truly unlimited in the ammount of text sent, received, and data sent. Really it comes down to how fast both partys wifi is. Kind of unrelated but this is why SMS/ MMS are total garbage when it comes to any video or picture taking. You can send a nice 4k video and when it's received on the other end it's so compressed to fit the maximum 4mb file format it looks like it was shot underwater through 50 panes of glass. Its really bad. iMessage Doesn't suffer from this since it's sneding all photos and videos through the wifi signal so it's essentially uncompressed.

You can receive a text with a messaging app connected by the wifi on the smartphone. You can't receive a SMS text though as that only works with the SIM card in the device. Just like you can't make or take a phone call without the SIM. There are apps like Skype that you could wifi call back and forth but a call or text on the cellular network would not be possible without a SIM. The SIM is what identifies you as you on the network and allows you access to the network.

Text messages, “SMS”, are going only through the SS7 GSM signalling network. Not through IP, so no via internet. Only GSM, which is secured by a SIM. No SIM, no GSM, no SS7… no SMS, no Text! Those SMS are coded via the SIM for security reasons.

Amazon couldn't find your house without an address. There are internet based messaging services such as Viber or kik but they operate differently and do not accept normal texts.

The SIM card is what identifies the phone to the network. It provides the linkage between the handset and your account with the wireless provider. No SIM, nothing wireless is happening. At least not with cellular connections. Yes, you can use Wi-Fi but that has no connection with SMS or phone calls. So, you can’t. Period.
